metadata.Name: XOR-TyDi QA
metadata.Description: XOR-TyDi QA is a large-scale cross-lingual open-retrieval question answering dataset. It includes questions in 7 typologically diverse languages (Arabic, Bengali, Finnish, Japanese, Korean, Russian, Telugu) with answers sourced from English Wikipedia. The dataset was created by translating and re-annotating information-seeking questions from TyDi QA.
Provider: The University of Texas at Austin
metadata.Venue Title: Proceedings of the 2021 Conference of the North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics: Human Language Technologies
metadata.Venue Name: Conference of the North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics: Human Language Technologies
Affiliations: The University of Texas at Austin
metadata.Abstract: Existing large-scale question answering (QA) datasets have shown that models can achieve strong performance when questions are answerable from a given context paragraph or a large document corpus. However, the problem of cross-lingual open-retrieval QA (XOR QA) has been under-explored, where questions are in one language and answers are in another, and the relevant documents must be retrieved from a large multilingual corpus. In this paper, we introduce a new large-scale XOR QA dataset, XOR-TyDi QA, which consists of questions in 7 typologically diverse languages and answers in English. We build this dataset by translating and re-annotating existing information-seeking questions from TyDi QA. We then use XOR-TyDi QA to define three XOR QA tasks: (1) XOR-Retrieve: given a non-English question, retrieve relevant English passages; (2) XOR-EnglishSpan: given a non-English question and relevant English passages, extract an English answer span; and (3) XOR-Full: given a non-English question, retrieve relevant English passages and extract an English answer span. We benchmark state-of-the-art monolingual and multilingual models, and show that there is a significant gap between model and human performance (20-30 F1 points), suggesting that XOR QA is a challenging task. We release our dataset and code at https://nlp.cs.washington.edu/xorqa/.
